Making LiOH this way in NOT smart. Lithium metal reacting in water does not need air to start a fire. What happens is that the metal gets hot enough and wets to the glass on the side of the flask. Then a reaction sets in and you get a flare up and your flask will be destroyed in an instant. I assume the lithium gets it's oxygen from the silica in the glass.

The SAFE way to do this is to start with your water frozen, pop some of the lithium in, and stick it right back in the freezer and let it go until the water starts to freeze back up again. Once your solution gets strong enough, you can safely react at room temperature.

Use the same technique to keep the initial part of the reaction safe when reacting with alcohols. I personally use a thick-walled DRAM with a pressure release top for these reactions.

My freezer is set to -10C

Additionally, any atmospheric exposure will destroy your LiOH by turning it to lithium carbonate in no time flat. My recommendation is that you forego preparing the actual dry powder when possible. I seriously doubt that NileRed's estimates of his purity are accurate as I've done all of this myself.

Shouldn't it be easier to reacting litium with a large excess of methanol, forming a litium methoxide solution. Then concentrate that to a syrup. Now you have a very concentrated solution of litium methoxide in methanol. Slowly add an equimolar amount of water and then distill off all the methanol. Initially you will have a equilibrium between methoxide and hydroxide. But as the methanol is removed the equilibrium is pushed towards hydroxide. By doing it like this you would not have to remove any excess water, which is a bitch, compared to removing methanol.
Instead of dropping lithium into water you can drop water into lithium slowly. I made in my home perfectly dry lithium hydroxide using this method

What about heating the water? That would greatly increase the reaction rate and the LiOH’s solubility. Or are you concerned about the reaction going out of control?
Also, evaporating sounds like a way better idea; vacuum filtering is going to result in a massive amount of carbonate conversion, since you’re actively pulling a lot of air through the lithium, compared to evaporation, which only exposes the surface.

It seems to me that if you could mix 2 liquids to produce lithium hydroxide, you wouldn't have the goopynoid issues. Try this.

Li + MeOH (excess) --------> CH3-OLi (in MeOH)

CH3-OLi (in MeOH) +. H2O (75 c, large excess) --------> LiOH (aq) + MeOH (g) (recovered)

Adding the lithium methoxide solution to 75 c hot water vaporizes and expels the MeOH from the reaction mixture literally as fast as it forms, driving the reaction forward to completion due to rapid loss of the MeOH product. By capturing the evolved MeOH in a condenser, it can be reclaimed. The resultant solution of LiOH is concentrated by heating until any desired concentration of Lithium Hydroxide can be achieved.
Tbh method 2 is more straightforward and obvious

So, it is better to prepare monoxide by burning the metal alone in dry oxygen (but it always contains some peroxide anyway). It can also be obtained by heating either Lithium carbonate or nitrate but again in atmosphere of hydrogen (to prevent the formation of peroxide)

I want to see the effects of acids on skin. I'm assuming that since you are still releasing videos, you still have two working hands.

In my organic chemistry class, the first time I handled concentrated sulfuric acid I didn't use gloves because the lab assistant had previously talked about how sulfuric acid would eat through gloves. When he discovered what I was doing, he reprimanded me and instructed me to use gloves for subsequent experiments. However, I always wondered what actually would have happened that one time if I had made a mistake and spilled the concentrated sulfuric acid on my hand.
